children.title: God, revelation of
children.comment: God graciously makes himself known to humanity since people cannot discover him on their own. He achieves this in many ways, but supremely through his Son Jesus Christ.

children.title: God is hidden from human view because of sin

cschildren.title: The means by which God reveals himself
The nature of God's self-revelation in Jesus Christ

children.title: God reveals Jesus Christ's true identity
Jesus Christ is the visible image of God
Jesus Christ's glory is still to be fully revealed

secondaryrefs.comment: the LORD shows his glory to Moses

primaryrefs.comment: ``mystery'' in the NT means ``something previously hidden, undiscoverable by human means but now revealed by God''.

children.title: Physical means by which God reveals his will
God's self-revelation makes his will plain

cschildren.title: God's self-revelation is according to his own sovereign purpose
God spoke to Moses through a bush which burned but was not consumed

children.title: dream
children.comment: A series of images or thoughts experienced in one's mind while asleep. A means by which a divine message may be conveyed while the recipient sleeps. God may communicate directly in the dream, or interpretation may be necessary.

cschildren.title: God is the source of interpretation of such dreams

primaryrefs.comment: Not every dream is a vehicle for divine communication.  Most are part of the natural process of sleep.

children.title: foreknowledge
children.comment: Foreknowledge is an aspect of God's knowledge of everything, and thus nothing can surprise him. Jesus Christ had foreknowledge of his own death, resurrection and coming in glory.

cschildren.title: God's foreknowledge and his election of his people

children.title: Of events within his general ministry
Of his coming in glory and judgment
Jesus Christ's lack of knowledge of the timing of his coming in glory
miracles
children.comment: Events that are totally out of the ordinary and that cannot be adequately explained on the basis of natural occurrences, such as those associated with the ministry of Jesus Christ. They are seen as evidence of the presence and power of God in the world or as demonstrating authority on the part of one of his servants.

children.title: miracles, nature of
children.comment: Miracles may be performed directly by God or through a human agent. Those recorded in Scripture include healing, raising the dead, miracles of nature and the casting out of demons.

children.title: Miracles demonstrate God's greatness and power
The provision of food and water
Miracles are part of God's plan of redemption
Miracles occur at times of special significance
At the time of the exodus
At times of national religious crisis
In the time of Jesus Christ
In the time of the first Christians
They authenticate the message of his servants
They are given by God's sovereign will
Miracles are not in themselves proof of God's work
They are no guarantee of genuine faith
miracles, responses to
children.comment: Miracles often depend upon faith on the part of those who will benefit from them. Human responses to miracles take various forms. Some respond in faith and obedience, whilst others are confirmed in their unbelief and rebellion.

children.title: Faith and obedience required in the working of miracles

primaryrefs.comment: The widow gave Elijah her last meal before she could be miraculously provided for.

children.title: Miracles limited by lack of faith

seealsos.comment: The number of jars limited the miraculous supply of oil

children.title: A closer attention paid to the word of God
Temporary faith as a response to miracles
miracles, nature of
children.comment: Miracles may be performed directly by God or through a human agent. Those recorded in Scripture include healing, raising the dead, miracles of nature and the casting out of demons.

children.title: Miracles demonstrate God's greatness and power
The provision of food and water
Miracles are part of God's plan of redemption

At the time of the exodus

In the time of Jesus Christ
In the time of the first Christians
They authenticate the message of his servants
They are given by God's sovereign will
Miracles are not in themselves proof of God's work
They are no guarantee of genuine faith
miracles, responses to
children.comment: Miracles often depend upon faith on the part of those who will benefit from them. Human responses to miracles take various forms. Some respond in faith and obedience, whilst others are confirmed in their unbelief and rebellion.

children.title: Faith and obedience required in the working of miracles

primaryrefs.comment: The widow gave Elijah her last meal before she could be miraculously provided for.

children.title: Miracles limited by lack of faith

seealsos.comment: The number of jars limited the miraculous supply of oil

children.title: A closer attention paid to the word of God
Temporary faith as a response to miracles
oracles
children.comment: Divine utterances or messages spoken through human lips. Especially noteworthy are the oracles of Balaam. Several other prophecies are also referred to as oracles.

seealsos.comment: This oracle involved actions as well as words

children.title: predictions
children.comment: Speaking authoritatively of the future. Since God knows the future he is able to reveal it to people beforehand. Predictions, which are often but not necessarily contained in prophecies, should not be confused with promises or expressions of intention.

cschildren.title: Impossible to predict the future apart from God

children.title: Concerning the donkey on which he would enter Jerusalem
Concerning the nature of Peter's death

cschildren.title: The ability to interpret dreams and so predict the future
Predictions were made through OT prophets
Predictions made through some of the first Christians

primaryrefs.comment: Most OT references to the coming of the kingdom of God and his Messiah are not, strictly speaking, predictions but promises made by God in which he expresses his intention to save his people through the Messiah.

children.title: prophecy
children.comment: The disclosing of the will and purposes of God through inspired or Spirit-filled human beings. The OT emphasises the importance of prophecy as a means of knowing God. Many OT prophecies find their fulfilment in Jesus Christ. The NT sets out the place of prophecy in the life of the church and gives guidance concerning the use of this gift.

children.title: prophecy, inspiration of OT
children.comment: The prophecies of biblical messengers are acknowledged as being of divine origin, inspired through the activity of the Holy Spirit.

children.title: God is the source of prophecy

primaryrefs.comment: The phrase ``the word of the LORD came to ...'' is frequently used of (and by) the prophets to indicate that the message they proclaimed came directly from God.

children.title: Prophets inspired by God speak the truth
prophecy, fulfilment of OT
children.comment: All divinely inspired prophecy achieves its purpose. Scripture records the fulfilment of many prophecies.

children.title: The principle that all prophecy achieves its purpose
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning individuals in the OT
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning the nation of Israel
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning the royal house
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning the Babylonian exile
The fall of Jerusalem and exile of the population
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning Jesus Christ
prophecy, methods of OT
children.comment: Prophets relayed their messages from God in a variety of ways, choosing methods that would make the meaning clear, attract attention or convince the people of the truth of their words.

children.title: Messages presented as coming from God

primaryrefs.comment: Prophets often used the phrases ``hear the word of the LORD'' and ``says the LORD'' to ensure that their audience understood the divine origin of their proclamation.

children.title: Prophecy expressed as an allegory or parable
Prophecy given by vision or dream
prophecy, in NT
children.comment: The NT describes the prophetic aspect of the ministry of Jesus Christ, and also recognises that prophetic gifts are given to believers through the Holy Spirit. It provides guidance on how such prophetic gifts are to be used.

children.title: Jesus Christ recognised as a prophet
Prophecy is one among many spiritual gifts
Not all are called to be prophets
Prophecy is for the building up of the church
Prophecy superior to speaking in tongues
prophecy, inspiration of OT
children.comment: The prophecies of biblical messengers are acknowledged as being of divine origin, inspired through the activity of the Holy Spirit.

children.title: God is the source of prophecy

primaryrefs.comment: The phrase ``the word of the LORD came to ...'' is frequently used of (and by) the prophets to indicate that the message they proclaimed came directly from God.

children.title: Prophets inspired by God speak the truth
prophecy, fulfilment of OT
children.comment: All divinely inspired prophecy achieves its purpose. Scripture records the fulfilment of many prophecies.

children.title: The principle that all prophecy achieves its purpose
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning individuals in the OT
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning the nation of Israel
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning the royal house
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning the Babylonian exile
The fall of Jerusalem and exile of the population
Fulfilment of prophecy concerning Jesus Christ

children.title: Messages presented as coming from God

primaryrefs.comment: Prophets often used the phrases ``hear the word of the LORD'' and ``says the LORD'' to ensure that their audience understood the divine origin of their proclamation.

children.title: Prophecy expressed as an allegory or parable
Prophecy given by vision or dream

children.comment: The NT describes the prophetic aspect of the ministry of Jesus Christ, and also recognises that prophetic gifts are given to believers through the Holy Spirit. It provides guidance on how such prophetic gifts are to be used.

children.title: Jesus Christ recognised as a prophet
Prophecy is one among many spiritual gifts
Not all are called to be prophets
Prophecy is for the building up of the church
Prophecy superior to speaking in tongues
reality
children.comment: Scripture provides an accurate and reliable guide to the realities of the spiritual and material worlds. It affirms the reality of human sin, of the power and purpose of God to deal with sin through Jesus Christ and of the guidance of the Holy Spirit.

children.title: The reality of the existence of God
The reality of the love of God
The reality of the revelation of God
The reality of the word of God
His reality foreshadowed in the past

cschildren.title: The reality of the guidance of the Holy Spirit

children.title: revelation
children.comment: The making known of God's person, nature and deeds, in Scripture, history and supremely the person of Jesus Christ. God is also made known, to a limited yet important extent, through his creation.

children.title: revelation, through creation
children.comment: The creation bears witness to the wisdom and power of its creator. This natural knowledge of God is limited in its extent, but is sufficient to convince human beings of the existence of God and the need to respond to him.

children.title: The creation bears witness to its creator
All human beings have a natural awareness of God
The limitations of a natural knowledge of God
revelation, necessity of
children.comment: Finiteness and sin make it impossible to gain adequate knowledge of God through human effort alone. God in mercy makes himself known through the incarnation of the Son and the illumination of human minds to understand him.

children.title: The impossibility of fully knowing God without revelation
God is beyond unaided human knowing
The human mind cannot discern God of its own accord
God is known fully only through Jesus Christ
revelation, in OT
children.comment: The OT bears witness to God's revelation in the history of Israel and in the inspired testimony of the prophets and other writers of the period. This knowledge of God prepares the way for the full disclosure of God in Jesus Christ in the NT.

children.title: Revelation in Eden and before the flood
The covenant framework of OT revelation after the flood

primaryrefs.comment: This covenant covers all living creatures.

children.title: God's covenant with Moses at Sinai

seealsos.comment: Mount Sinai was also known as Mount Horeb

children.title: The promise of a new covenant
On occasions God spoke to people outside the covenant community
Revelation of God's will and purposes
Revelation of God's character and being

primaryrefs.comment: The fulness of God's redemption could only become apparent with the fulness of his revelation in Jesus Christ.

children.title: revelation, in NT
children.comment: The NT fulfils and completes the revelation of God which began in the OT. Jesus Christ is the central focus of this self-revelation of God.

children.title: The unity and progress of revelation
The unity of OT and NT

seealsos.comment: The writings of Paul are presented as having equal status with the OT Scriptures
These sanctions have the same force as those of Dt 4:2; 12:32.

children.title: The NT fulfils and completes God's revelation of himself
Jesus Christ is the supreme revelation of God
Jesus Christ is the image of God
Jesus Christ has the nature of God
Jesus Christ is the exact representation of God
Jesus Christ is the incarnate Word of God
The role of the Holy Spirit in revelation
He is the divine agent of revelation
He is the source of revelatory manifestations
To reveal himself in Jesus Christ
To reveal his plan through Jesus Christ
revelation, responses to
children.comment: God requires and imparts a frame of mind that receives and responds to what he has made known.

children.title: God commands that his word be heeded
People do not naturally understand what God has revealed
They fail to recognise God's revelation in Jesus Christ
They fail to understand God's revelation in general
God has given his Spirit to illuminate the human mind
He reveals through prayer for understanding
Understanding God's revelation carries special responsibility
God's revelation of himself will only be fully understood at the second coming of Jesus Christ
The consequences of responding to revelation

children.comment: The creation bears witness to the wisdom and power of its creator. This natural knowledge of God is limited in its extent, but is sufficient to convince human beings of the existence of God and the need to respond to him.

children.title: The creation bears witness to its creator
All human beings have a natural awareness of God

signs
children.comment: Miraculous or supernatural confirmations of the existence and power of God or the miraculous demonstration of spiritual authority on the part of an individual.

children.title: signs, purposes of
children.comment: Signs are given to confirm God's word. They may warn the rebellious or encourage the faithful. People may seek signs as a result of a genuine desire to serve God.

children.title: Signs are given to demonstrate God's power
Signs demonstrate the authority of God's servants
Signs may accompany the preaching of the gospel
Signs may warn the ungodly of impending judgment
Signs may warn God's people against rebellion
By giving assurance of God's presence
By encouraging the fearful and doubting
Signs need hold no terror for the godly
When seeking signs is acceptable to God
When seeking signs is condemnned by God
signs, kinds of
children.comment: Signs are miraculous events, supernatural phenomena or everyday things that are given a special significance. The term is used in John's Gospel to describe the miracles of Jesus Christ.

children.title: The signs of Jesus Christ in John's Gospel

primaryrefs.comment: John refers to the miracles of Jesus Christ as ``signs'' in order to bring out the significance of these deeds.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ, the bread of life
Jesus Christ, the light of the world
Jesus Christ, the resurrection and the life

children.title: Jesus Christ refers to Jonah as a sign
Signs serve as reminders of past blessings
Signs associated with the birth of Jesus Christ
Signs associated with the death of Jesus Christ
The curtain of the temple torn in two
The dead came back to life
Signs associated with the coming of the Holy Spirit
The sound like a violent wind
Signs associated with the second coming of Jesus Christ
Signs simultaneous with the second coming
signs, purposes of
children.comment: Signs are given to confirm God's word. They may warn the rebellious or encourage the faithful. People may seek signs as a result of a genuine desire to serve God.

children.title: Signs are given to demonstrate God's power
Signs demonstrate the authority of God's servants
Signs may accompany the preaching of the gospel

When seeking signs is condemnned by God

theophany
children.comment: A temporary visible manifestation of the presence and glory of God. This may be in natural phenomena such as cloud or fire, in human form or in prophetic visionary experience.

children.title: God's presence in storms, thunder and lightning

cschildren.title: Specific phenomena associated with the presence of God

primaryrefs.comment: Fire in particular represents the purity, holiness and unapproachability of God.
Cloud and smoke convey the mystery and transcendence of God.

cschildren.title: God is manifested in human or angelic form

primaryrefs.comment: John interprets this verse to refer to Jesus Christ (Jn 12:41).

children.title: God appears attended by angels and other heavenly beings
God appears like, or with, precious stones
Theophanies arouse the fear of God
trance
children.comment: An ecstatic state in which people may be aware of God communicating with them; it may cause them to lose control of their actions or to have abnormal strength.

cschildren.title: God communicating with people through a trance
Examples of the Holy Spirit's domination of individuals in a trance-like manner

children.title: King Saul and his men pursuing David

cschildren.title: Under the influence of the Holy Spirit people may act with abnormal strength

children.title: truth
children.comment: Truth in Scripture is more than mere veracity. In the OT it is a moral concept, grounded in the being of God himself, which embodies the ideas of faithfulness and reliability, while in the NT the concept widens to embrace the ideas of reality and completeness.

children.title: truth, nature of
children.comment: God is the essence of truth and this quality should be reflected in the character of his children. Falsehood is condemned in Scripture, particularly in legal contexts, but truth is praised and advocated. God takes pleasure in truth and honesty, which are marks of an upright person.

children.title: Truth is an aspect of God's character
It is demonstrated in his faithfulness and reliability
It is demonstrated in his justice and mercy

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebraic concept of truth embraces the ideas of faithfulness, reliability and justice.

children.title: Truth should be reflected in the character of God's people
Absence of truth in the human character displeases God
Truth is the opposite of falsehood
Lack of truth is a characteristic of apostasy
Truth as an expression of affirmation
Amen as a liturgical affirmation of truth

primaryrefs.comment: The word ``amen'' is closely related to the word for ``truth'' in Hebrew. It constitutes an affirmation of the truth of what has been said and an acceptance of its consequences.
By NT times, the word ``Amen'' had become a common liturgical phrase of affirmation, used after prayers, benedictions and doxologies.

children.title: truth, in NT
children.comment: The NT encompasses the Greek idea of truth as reality, as well as the Hebraic concepts of faithfulness and reliability. Jesus Christ is shown as ``the Truth'' and the apostles present the gospel as ``truth''.

children.title: Truth as opposed to falsehood and lies
Truth as an aspect of the character of God
The Spirit of God as truth
The gospel and the Christian faith as truth
truth, nature of
children.comment: God is the essence of truth and this quality should be reflected in the character of his children. Falsehood is condemned in Scripture, particularly in legal contexts, but truth is praised and advocated. God takes pleasure in truth and honesty, which are marks of an upright person.

children.title: Truth is an aspect of God's character
It is demonstrated in his faithfulness and reliability
It is demonstrated in his justice and mercy

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebraic concept of truth embraces the ideas of faithfulness, reliability and justice.

children.title: Truth should be reflected in the character of God's people
Absence of truth in the human character displeases God
Truth is the opposite of falsehood
Lack of truth is a characteristic of apostasy

Amen as a liturgical affirmation of truth

primaryrefs.comment: The word ``amen'' is closely related to the word for ``truth'' in Hebrew. It constitutes an affirmation of the truth of what has been said and an acceptance of its consequences.
By NT times, the word ``Amen'' had become a common liturgical phrase of affirmation, used after prayers, benedictions and doxologies.

children.title: truth, in NT
children.comment: The NT encompasses the Greek idea of truth as reality, as well as the Hebraic concepts of faithfulness and reliability. Jesus Christ is shown as ``the Truth'' and the apostles present the gospel as ``truth''.

children.title: Truth as opposed to falsehood and lies
Truth as an aspect of the character of God
The Spirit of God as truth
The gospel and the Christian faith as truth
vision
children.comment: Scripture uses the term to refer to both the physical act of seeing, and also the gift of spiritual insight. All things, physical and spiritual, are seen by God.

children.title: God views all life on earth
God sees the hearts and thoughts of people

cschildren.title: The physical vision of human beings

children.title: It is given and can be taken by God
Jesus Christ restores the sight of the blind

secondaryrefs.comment: Ecc 12:2-5 is an allegory on ageing. It gives a graphic description of a person's progressive deterioration.

cschildren.title: Christians are to live by faith rather than by sight

children.title: Examples of those who saw God
Seeing used metaphorically for spiritual insight

seealsos.comment: Jerusalem was called ``the Valley of Vision'', possibly ironically, for although God spoke through his prophets and dwelt there, its inhabitants lacked insight

children.title: Spiritual insight given in dreams or visions

seealsos.comment: Daniel's dream of four beasts
Daniel's vision of a man
Peter's vision
Paul's vision of the man of Macedonia

children.title: The OT prophets had visions from God
False prophets in the OT lacked true vision
visions
children.comment: Mental pictures used by God to convey messages or reveal future events. They are normally received in private by individuals who are often prophets.

cschildren.title: God speaks to individuals in visions
Visions may contain unusual or startling images
False visions associated with lying prophets
Visions associated with the outpouring of the Holy Spirit
